newsitem.title: ITALY: Air Littoral airline plans third French hub.
newsitem.headline: Air Littoral airline plans third French hub.

text.p: French regional airline Air Littoral plans a third hub at either Toulouse or Bordeaux to serve the Spanish market, the airline's manager for Italy's Veneto-Trentino-Friuli region, Eric Ingargiola, told reporters on Friday.
However, this was not planned before 1998, he said.
Air Littoral, majority-owned by French businessman Michel Seydoux, already operates out of Montpelier and Nice, covering France and Italy respectively.

The airline has a marketing and ticket code-sharing agreement with Lufthansa and as part of the cooperation pact Air Littoral plans to issue eight-year convertible bonds to Lufthansa which will allow the German company to buy up to 15 percent of the French firm's capital.
It also operates 29 national and international routes for Air France.
Air Littoral has a fleet of 30 planes, including 15 ATR 42-500s, and is spending $133 million for seven new Canadair regional jets to be delivered by end-1997 with an option for a further five.

The company, with total capital of 63.8 million French francs and 100 percent owned by Cie Francaise d'Investissement Aeronautique, part of the Seydoux group, aims for a Paris bourse listing by the end of this year.
The airline carried 1.8 million passengers in the 1996/97 financial year ending on March 31, some 100,000 up on the previous year.
Ingargiola said the load factor on its Nice-Venice route averaged 63 percent, well above that on its other six Italian routes, from Nice to Milan, Bologna, Florence, Rome, Naples and Olbia.
